posts.name: Inara Mitchell
posts.cooked: My CNC machine was working just fine a moment ago but suddenly it stopped responding to the controller and my computer. When I try to move it with the controller it shows that it‚Äôs not moving. The x,y, and z axis does not change. Before that it wasn‚Äôt hitting the Z limit switch and was constantly trying to go up and up. Then we restarted it and it completely stopped.
When you turned it off, did you manually move the knobs on your z axis to make sure it was no longer hitting the limit switch before you turned it back on?

posts.name: Inara Mitchell
posts.cooked: No we didnt move the knobs.
Manually move the Z axis away from your limit switch while the machine is off. Turn it all back on, reset so that you are not estopped, and then try to jog the machine.

posts.name: Inara Mitchell
posts.cooked: We just did that it doesn‚Äôt work. The mill does not move at all.
Can you specify which machine you‚Äôre using? Some of them have quirks, which unfortunately require restarting multiple times, or doing other steps in case of a machine crash.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: And you‚Äôve checked you didn‚Äôt trip any breakers or fuses, right?

suggested_topics.fancy_title: Swerve module physically unable to drive and rotate at the same time
suggested_topics.title: Swerve module physically unable to drive and rotate at the same time
suggested_topics.excerpt: All the coaxial swerves have an interaction between rotating and steering. IE, steering causes the wheel to rotate a bit. Just bake it into your programming
